Clerval spoke this as we huried
thou through the streets the words
impressed themselves on my memor
mind and I remembered them afterwads
in solitude. As soon But now, as soon
as the horses arrived I hurried into
a Cabriolet and left Ingo bad fare
well to my friend.
My journey was very melancholy.
At first I wished to hurry on for I longed
to console & sympathize withmy loved and
sorrowing friends but when I drew
near my t native town I sla
^
c kened
my pace progress . I C I could hardly sustain
the multitude of feelings that
crowed crowded into my mind. I passed
though scee scenes familiar to my youth
but which I had not seen for nearly
five years, how altered every thing might
be during since that time? one great sudden
and desolating change had taken place
but a thousand little circumstance
might have sapped
worked
by degreed degrees
worked worked others
t
as great alterations
^
which although
it might be done more tranquilly would
not be less de s c isive. Fear overcame me
I dared had N not advance fea dreading
a thoug thousand nameless evils that
made me tremble while although I could not was unable
to define them.
I remained thus at Lausanne for
two days not daring to proceed. I contem
plated the lake – the waters were
placid – all around was calm and the
Snowy mountains the "Palaces of Nature" X
X Lord Byron
were not changed. By degrees, this calm
and heavenly scene restored me, and I
proceeded
continued my
journey towards Geneva. The road
ran by the side of the lake which
became narrower as I approached
my native town – I discovered more
distinctly the black sides of Jura;
and the
^
bright summit of Mount Blanc–
I wept like a child– Dear mountains
my own beautiful lake how do you
welcome your wanderer Your sum
mits are clear the sky and lake
are blue is this
^
to prognosticate peace
or to mock
my unhappiness?
I fear, my friend to
^
that I shall render myself
tedious by dwelling on these preliminary
circumstances but they were days of
comparative happiness and I dwell
^
think
o n f them with pleasure – My Country
my beloved country Who
^
but a native can tell the
delight I took in again beholding thy
st
^
r eams thy mountains and more than
all thy lovely lake and
Yet as I drew nearer home grief and
fear overcame me – night also closed
round me and when I could hardly
see the dark mountains I felt still
more gloomily I pictured to mysel f every
evil and persuaded myself that
the most I was destined to become
the most whretched of human beings–
Alas! I prho prophesied truly and
failed onlyin one single circumstance: that in all the misery
I imagined and dreaded, I did not conceive
of the hundredth part of the anguish
I
I was
destined to feel . endure.
Chapter 10
Night had closed
^
in when I arrived and
the gates of Geneva were already closed
^
shut and
I determined to remain that night at
Secheron
a village
half a league
to the east
-ward of the city . The night sky was very fine serene and
unable as I was unable to rest I resolved
to walk toward s visit the spot where m
y
poor William had been murdered;
as I walked I perceived a storm collecting
on the other side of the lake. I saw the
lightnings play in the most beautiful
figures and gained a summit
that I might observe the
^
its progress.
It advanced slowly and and I soon felt
the rain coming slowly in large
drops but its violence quickly encreased.
I quitted my seat and walk on,
although the darkness and storm aug
mented every minute and the thunder
burst violently over with a terrific
crash over my head — William I ex
cried aloud – dear angel this is thy
funeral this thy dirge. It was echoed
from Salêve
^
the Jura and the Alps of Savoy—
vivid flashes of lightning dazzled my
eyes, and illumin ed ating the lake; and
then for an instant every thing
seemed of a pitchy black
^
darkness
til untill
the eye recovered itself from the
^
preceeding flash.
A The storm as is often the case in
that country Switzerland appeared at once in various
parts of the heavens. The most violent
storm was hung exactly noth north of the town
and at over that part where of the lake
^
turns which at
lies between
the promontory of Belrive and changing the
village of Copet its course from South to north which
it before p
u rsue s d proceeds from west
to east — another storm enlightened
Jura with faint flashes and another
appeared darkened and sometimes
disclosed the Mole – the name of
a peaked mountain to the east of
the lake.
While I watched the storm – so beauti
ful yet terrific I wandered listlessly
on with a hasty step – I felt that
th is e noble war in the sky elevated
my spirits; I clasped my hands & ex
claimed aloud "William, dear angel,
this is thy funeral, this thy dirge!"–
As I said these words a flash of lightning I perceived in the gloom
discovered to me a figure which stole from
behind a clump of trees near me – X
I stood
fixed gazing
intently, I
could not
be mista
ken a
flash of
lightning
illumined
the object,
and discov
ered to me
I stood
aghast its gigantc stanture , its & the deformity
of its aspectmore hideous tha t n
a man could be belongs to humanity
explain instantly informed me who it
was. It was the wretch, the filthy dæmon to
whom I had given life. What did he there?
Could he be (I shuddered at the conception
the murderer of my brother. No sooner
did that idea cross my imagination than
I became convinced
^
of its truth — my teeth chattered
and I was forced to lean against th a
tree for support — The figure quickly passed
me and I lost it in the gloom. And
h H e
therefore was the murderer! I
^
could not doubted it not my
the thought was agony
^
I was agonized by the bare probability
Nothingin human
shape could
have destroyed
that fair
child. He
was the
murderer!
I could not
doubt it.
The mere presence
of the idea
was an ir
resistible
proof of the
fact
— I thought of pur
sueing the devil, but
^
it would have been in vain for another
flash discovered him to me climbing
up the steep and hanging among the rocks of the nearly perpendicular
ascent of the Mont-Salêve; he soon reached
the summit and dissap p e ared.
I remained motionless the thunder
ceased but the rain still continued &
the scene was inveloped in a n pitchy
^
impenetrable
dark
ness. I revolved in my mind I revolved in
my mind
I resolved in my mind
the events which I u had,
untill now, sought to forget. ^
The whole
train of my
progress to
wards my
creation
The appearance
of the creature
^
the work of my own hands, alive at my bed side – & its departure.
Its It was now nearly two years
^
had now nearly elapsed since the
night of on which he first received
life, and was this his first crime – ? Alas!
I
^
had turned loose in the world a depraved
wretch whose delight was in deat
murder & wretchedness; For for had he
not murdered my brother?
No one can conceive of the anguish I
suff er e red during the remainder of the
night which I spent
^
cold & wet in the open
air. cold and wet. But I did not
feel th i e s
^
incovenience of the weather. my imagination was busy in
in scene scenes of ev e i l and despair
I considered the wh wretch being whom I
had cast in among mankind for pu
and
endowed with
the will &
the power
to effect
purposes of mischief horror such as this the deed which he had now done, nearly in the light
of my ow vampire; my own spirit let
loose from the grave and forced to
destroy all who were dear to me.
Day dawned and I directed my
steps towards the town – the gates were
open and I hastened to my father's
houses.–My n first thought was to disco
ver what I knew of the murderer &
cause instant search pursuit to
be made. But I paused when I reflect
ed what the story was that I had
to tell. A creature being whom I myself
had created and endued with life,
had met
me at mid
night among
the
precipices of
an inaccessi
ble mountain The
story
tale
was utterly improbable and I knew
well that if any other had related communicated such
a tale
^
relation to me I should have looked
upon it as the ravings of delirium
Besides the strange nature of the
animal would elude all the us
elude pursuit, even if I were so far
believed
credited
which was
^
utterly impossible as to persuade its self my relatives to commence it – the com
mon people would believe it to
be a real devil and who could attempt
Besides of what use
would be pursuit?
Who could
arrest
a creature that could capable of scal e ing the
steep
overhanging
sides of Mont-Salêve? These
reflections determined me, and I resolved
to be
^
remain silent.
It was about five in the morning when
I entered my fathers house. I told the servants
not to disturb the family, and went into
the library to attend their usual time of
rising. Five years had elapsed–passed as
a dream but for one indelible trace, and
I stood in the same place where I had last
embraced my father before my departure
for Ingolstadt. Beloved and respectable
parent! His chair was before the reading
desk and a book open He still remained
to me. I gazed on a picture of my mother
which stood over the mantlepiece. It was
an historical piece painted to please my
father and represented Caroline Beaumont
in an agony of despair kneeling by the coffin
of her dead father. Her garb was rustic, & her
cheek pale but there was an air of dignity
and beauty that hardly allowed of
^
permitted the
feeling sentiment of pity. Below this picture was a
miniature of William, and my tears
flowed when I looked upon it—While I was
thus engaged Ernest entered– he had heard
me arrive and hastened to welcome me.
He expressed the greatest delight on seeing
me – "Welcome my dearest Victor," said he,
ah I wish you had come three weeks
months ago and then you would have been
welcomed as you ought
found
us all joy
ous & de
lighted
